content.question: A <math alttext="3 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> horizontal disk of radius <math alttext="0.2 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.2</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> rotates about its center with an angular velocity of <math alttext="50 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>rad/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The edge of the horizontal disk is placed in contact with a wall, and the disk comes to rest after <math alttext="10 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following situations associated with linear impulse is analogous to the angular impulse that is described?

choices.label: A <math alttext="3 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> block is initially at rest. An applied force of <math alttext="3 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is applied to the block, but the block does not move.

A <math alttext="3 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> block is initially at rest. A net force of <math alttext="3 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is applied to the block until it has a speed of <math alttext="10 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A <math alttext="3 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> block is initially traveling at <math alttext="10 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. An applied force of <math alttext="3 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is applied to the block in the direction of its velocity vector for <math alttext="10 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A <math alttext="3 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> block is initially traveling at <math alttext="10 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>10</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block encounters a <math alttext="3 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> frictional force until the block eventually stops.

content.answer: A <math alttext="3 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> block is initially traveling at <math alttext="10 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>10</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block encounters a <math alttext="3 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> frictional force until the block eventually stops.

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
